title: GSK And HSBC Bosses Back New China Trade Push
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Tue, Oct 20, 2015, 20:21 BST - UK Markets closed GSK And HSBC Bosses Back New China Trade Push By (c) Sky News 2015 | Sky News – 1 hour 17 minutes ago View Photo 

The bosses of some of Britain's biggest businesses, including GlaxoSmithKline (Other OTC: GLAXF - news ) , HSBC and WPP Group, are to join a panel being set up to boost bilateral trade between the UK and China. 
Sky News understands that the China-Britain Business Council (CBBC) will on Wednesday appoint approximately 15 chairs and chief executives of FTSE-100 companies, and a similar number of senior figures from professional services firms to serve on a new advisory council. 
Its members will comprise business leaders whose companies have a major presence in China at a time when ministers are attempting to usher in a "golden period" for the two countries' relationship. 
The announcement will be made to coincide with a slew of trade announcements to be made during a business summit at the Mansion House in the City, which will be a centrepiece of the state visit to Britain by China's president, Xi Jinping. 
Among the members of the advisory council will be Douglas Flint, the HSBC Holdings (HKSE: 0005.HK - news ) chairman; Sir Martin Sorrell, WPP chief executive; Sir Gerry Grimstone, chairman of Standard Life (LSE: SL.L - news ) ; Malcolm Sweeting, senior partner of Clifford Chance; Ralf Speth, the boss of Jaguar Land Rover; Sam Walsh, chief executive of Rio Tinto (LSE: RIO.L - news ) ; Xavier Rolet, the London Stock Exchange Group chief executive; and Sir Mike Rake, who chairs BT Group (LSE: BT-A.L - news ) and Worldpay. 
Sir Andrew Witty, the GlaxoSmithKline boss, will also be among the members despite the drugs company's £300m fine for bribing doctors imposed just over a year ago. 
Two university vice-chancellors from King's College London and Nottingham will also be appointed to the panel. 
A source said the aim of the group would be to advise CBBC "on how to encourage more companies to engage with China, here in the UK, in China and in third markets across the globe". 
"The launch of the advisory council at the time of the state visit demonstrates the commitment of CBBC and wider business to supporting the UK's collective effort to maximise opportunities with China," the source added. 
Billions of pounds-worth of trade deals will be announced during Mr Xi's visit, which David Cameron has said will be directly responsible for the creation of thousands of British jobs. 
George Osborne, the Chancellor, has referred to a "golden period" for relations between the two countries, with alliances including an agreement for China to take a one-third stake in the new nuclear power station at Hinkley Point; and an investment by Huawei, the telecoms giant, in a research project at the University of Manchester. 
However, Mr Xi's visit has already been overshadowed by thousands more job losses in the UK steel industry, which are partly attributable to the glut of cheap Chinese steel flooding international markets. 
Mr Cameron has pledged to "raise the issue" with the Chinese President, but unions have questioned the value of such an intervention. 
The CBBC could not be reached for comment on Tuesday.
